pageContext.desc: From author Willa Cather to her childhood friend and lifelong correspondent.

pages.transcription:
IMAGE W.S.C.  

                                                                                                         August 15

My Dear Mr. Clemens;
I write to express my appreciation of the honor you do me in offering me an Honorary Vice Presidency of the Mark Twain Society.
Very sincerely yours,
Willa Cather
--
From Willa Cather                                                                            Advise correspondents or publishers of your correct address.--Stamped
WHALE COVE GRAND MANAN Stamped                                         Removed 1902--Stamped upside down
NEW BRUNSWICK Stamped                                                             [[NORTH Unclear HEA?? AM AU 26 29 N.B.--Marrked]]
CANADA Stamped                                                                         IMAGE CANADA 2 cent stamp - unclear

    Mr. Cyril Clemens
    37 Gray Avenue
    Webster Grove
    Missouri
    U.S.A.

IMAGE W..S.C.

                                                         570 Park Avenue
                                                         New York
                                                         November 21st

Dear Mr. Clemens;
I am home at last.  after a long absence. I regret that I cannot go in to St. Louis for the Birthday Dinner. Up in the country I have been rereading Huckleberry Finn, probably for the twentieth time, and I am full of my old enthusiasm for it.  Have you seen

the very fine article on "Dickens and Mark Twain" by Stephen Leacock in the last number of The Yale Review underlined? It is our best literary magazine, I think.
I will be proud and happy to recieve the medal at any time.time. You can safely send it to me at this address.
Cordially yours
Willa Cather

IMAGE \W.S.C.
570 Park Avenue
December 26thunderlined
Dear Mr. Clemens:
It will give me great pleasure to receive the medal from the International Mark Twain Society, and I appreciate the honor which the Society confers in this award. I have always been proud of a story which Albert Bigelow Paine tells in his life crossed out Life of Mark Twain. It seems that your father once found an

early poem of mine re-printed in a newspaper, and he showed it to Mr. Paine and commended it with some enthusiasm. I think Mr. Paine quoted several stanzas of the poem in his book-- the third volume, if I remember rightly. I was a very young writer at that time, but a word from Mark Twain, spoken to a third person, meant a great deal to me.
Very sincerely yours
Willa Cather
Excuse my tardy reply to your letter; I have just returned from Northern Canada

From Willa Cather
570 Park AvenueNew York City
[[Stamped New York, N.Y. St.V 1933
December28, 1933 4:30 PM]]

Mr. Cyril Clemens
Webster Grove

W.S.C. Image
January 12th underlined
My Dear Mr. Clemens;
As I am going abroad immediately it will be impossible for me to serve as a judge in the proposed contest. Thank you for the invitation.
Very sincerely yours,
Willa Cather

IMAGE W.S.C
March 15
Dear Mr. Clemens;
I have just returned from a hurried trip to the ?Pacific coast, and find your very kind letter awaiting me. I should, of course, be very oleased to have your forthcoming  booklet on Housman dedicated to me. But since your letter is dated

[[Note:portion of letter not imaged] - back of prior page]]
drawing of Housman in William Archer’s “Modern English Poets?”
Sincerely yours
Willa Cather

New York, N.Y. MAR 193710AM

IMAGE LITHOGRAPH The Waldorf-Astoria New York
Annotated 10 Feb 1921
Dear Mary
If you are not doing anything tomorrow afternoon, why not come in for tea? I’ve been tied up with things and people all week, but I’d love to see you on Friday.
Yours,
Willie

undated
My dear Mary, Just a little bouquet from your old and true friend. You have borne life and sorrow bravely, but I love you for it. 
Willie
A final greeting to an old and valued friend, Willie and Elsie

August 8 [1935?]
Here we are, beyond the Azores, and the splendid autumn flowers you and Irene sent me still make our dinner table lovely day after day and turn my thoughts to my dear friends at home. So far we have had a rather rough passage, heavy seas with intense heat - a rather unusual combination. I was terribly tired when we left New York, but Mary Virginia came down to the boat with

us and my __ big steamer trunk had all my toilet things so deftly that I set off with a neat cabin. Before we were out of the narrows I went to bed and stayed there for 24 hours. For the first time in my life I had dinner and breakfast in bed on shipboard! Yesterday I began to feel like ____, and today I am enjoying everything. I am never sea sick, but to be terribly tired is about as bad. 
This letter is for Irene as well as Mary, and I will be

W.S.C. Imprinted
December t, [1936]
My dear Mary;
Such a long while I have wanted to write you, but life hurries me along so fast. I have just come back from Washington where I went because of the illness of an old and dear friend- whom I left much better much when I came away. but my going just me ten days behind with all my unclear unclear here.
I did not

Christmas Greetings

IMAGE Christmas greetings and all good wishes for your happiness in the New Year
slept badly. God bless you for your sweet letter, dear Mary. I wish I could take your pretty hand and thank you in a way more real than words.
Your dear friend
Willie

Dear Mary; Such a lovely letter from you! I made me cry, but it brought me great peace. You see, when I last saw Irene she was going to a doctor for the reoccurrence of an old trouble. She barely was a little nervous about it. Ever since then I have been afraid that she was ill and did not want to tell me. I wrote to Carrie and asked her. No reply. It looked worse and worse! I did worry a lot, especially when I was tired, and at night when I

Marked GRAND CENT. ANNEX.N.Y.6 Dec 22 1936 1 PM
Mrs. E. C. Creighton

A happy voyage to you,
dear Mary, and I hope you will fell my thoughts following you out to sea!
Willie

IMAGE THE SEASON’S BEST WISHES
With Love and Thank you
For not trying to punish me. As Undset Sigrid Undset says, with a shake of her wise head, “It’s so easy to punish us when we are down.”
Happy New Year!
Willie

I want you to have this book because it was sent to me by Undset Sigrid Undset herself, and because you have been in Norway.
Willie

Imprinted W.S.C.
June 5th
annotated in pencil  1935
Dear Mr. Weisz;
I have been worried about Irene ever since she went home. If she is not underlined I’ll, please scold her for me and urge her to write to me. If she is ill, please write me a line yourself and

Tell me how she is. Isn’t the Republican Valley undergoing all the Plagues of Egypt?
With my heart’s loyalty to you both.
Willa Cather
reversed W.S.C. visible on left

May 30, 1900
Dear Irene; unclear Douglas? and I went over unclear yesterday. The old Just of Albuquerque is very unclear
We have had a glorious time hunting Cliff Dwellers and things. I expect to be home in less than a week. W.S.C.

[[Laguna (the lake) was founded in 1699 and is the youngest of the pueblos  with about 1,000 inhabitants. It is 66 mikes West of Albuquerque and is perched upon a sterile hill, in a compact cluster.  This form of habitation was the outcome of the needs of the people. It is a fortress and built with every eye alert to its defensive qualities. The Pueblo Indians tilled the soil and provided for their needs; their neighbors were nomadic and warlike. The entrance was originally by means of a ladder to the roof of the lowest story.]]
Marked -EL PASO, TEX.

THIS SPACE MAY BE USED FOR MESSAGE. THIS SPACE FOR THE ADDRESS

[[IMAGE NUMBER FIVE BANK STREET [Annotated in pencil 13 Jan 1923]
Saturday
My Dearest Irene:
I arrived last night - two hours late, but without further misadventure. My cold is no worse  - rather better, if anything, but I’m keeping quiet. I am not going to open the [unclear] basket full of letters that await me until I'm rested. Josephine says I am to tell you that she is furious with you, as we had hoped that I would come straight from from eating roots chez ma mere, underlined, and would find her cooking delicious, whereas I do nothing, she insists, but tell her what wonderful things I had to eat in Chicago. But Edith agrees with me that if you hadn't taken me in and been so good to me I would probably still be languishing in some hospital in Chicago.

pageContext.title: Willa Cather and Irene Miner Weisz letters, 1912-1958
